It's especially annoying since absolutely nothing has changed at those critical places in the Android P master until now.

There are lot more usages of Unsafe than the few that you mentioned. I surely could get rid of some of them, but unlikely all of them (as this would cripple the functionality especially for parallel use cases).

I'll have to let sink that in and think about it. Also, seems I need an additional device for Android P testing now ;)

One possible approach could be to fork streamsupport a second time (android-retrostreams being the first fork), this time creating a version that is targeted especially at Android that shares no code with the JVM version in those critical areas.
As I said, I have to think about it. However, nothing will happen during the next two weeks (I'm away on vacation).

Pertaining to DexGuard: that's simply great! May I ask why you've decided to use streamsupport instead of android-retrostreams?

Regards,
Stefan", 'Hi Stefan,

indeed, a quick grep of the codebase shows much more uses of reflection.
I understand that in more recent Android versions, the functionality is delegated to the native implementation whenever possible, maybe this can also be extended for these cases?

Anyway I can also try to help with this, although it is not super urgent for us right now, as we still have to see what Android P will actually change, the results are all based on the latest developer previews.

I sticked to the original streamsupport library, because it allowed to translate the API calls quite simply. If there are default & static methods that are possibly translated by different tools (Android studio desugar, retrolambda, DexGuard itself), the translation mechanism would have to adapt to these tools, which are also subject to change (I especially learned not to rely too much on google android tools :-).

Anyways, very nice project and I hope that we can offer an open-source solution to use the library with the original Java 8 API very soon.

btw. it would also be nice if there would be a different way to disable the delegation to the native implementation. Using system properties does not feel right on Android and is difficult to instrument. An additional hard-coded flag would be much simpler, as we can easily change that when instrumenting the code.', 'Hi Thomas,

working backwards ...

disabling delegation / system property: yeah, that's right, it's not Android style. I've initially used that approach on Java 8 and simply adopted it when I introduced delegation for Android 7.
What do you mean by "hard-coded flag"? A "static final" something that you'd set by instrumentation? Can you give me an example?

As to why you've chosen streamsupport - I see, makes sense. Android tools - same here ;)

The places where Unsafe or any other kind of reflection is hard to replace have mostly to do with fork/join (parallel streams).
I've always wondered how important that use case is on Android devices. Do you have any data points (or an opinion) about this?

Regards,
Stefan', 'Hi Stefan,

for the delegation issue, I had something like this in mind:

static boolean DELEGATION_ENABLED_VIA_INSTRUMENTATION = true;
static final boolean DELEGATION_ENABLED = getBooleanPropVal(DELEGATION_ENABLED_P, true) && DELEGATION_ENABLED_VIA_INSTRUMENTATION;

It is important the the field DELEGATION_ENABLED_VIA_INSTRUMENTATION is not final as otherwise the compiler would inline its value.

But after reading the Known_Problems.txt and looking at the relevant source code, I wonder if this is even necessary anymore. From Spliterators.java:

if (HAS_STREAMS && (DELEGATION_ENABLED || IS_JAVA9) && !hasAndroid7LHMBug(c)) {
      // always use spliterator delegation on Java 9 from 1.5.6 onwards
      // https://sourceforge.net/p/streamsupport/tickets/299/
      return delegatingSpliterator(c);
}

Does this mean that delegation is disabled by default for API 24 & 25 for LinkedHashMaps?
Probably the Known_Problems.txt has to be updated as it is mentioned that delegation is enabled by default and has to be disabled on Android 24 & 25 to avoid the bug (or use a slightly modified code).', "Hi Thomas,

I've introduced that additional LHM check measure as a precaution for users that don't read (or understand) this note.

Yes, LinkedHashMaps are exempt from Spliterator delegation on API 24/25 even if Spliterator delegation is enabled generally.
However this works only insofar as it can be detected at runtime that the Collection views come from a LHM. For example, wrap a LHM in a Collections.UnmodifiableMap and you are screwed. If you want to guard against such cases you either have to disable Spliterator delegation altogether or manually program around this Android 7.x bug.

That's what I wanted to express in this note. Obviously, I didn't fully succeed.

As for the DELEGATION_ENABLED_VIA_INSTRUMENTATION switch - I have no problems with that as long as it can be package private.

I've thought about that shortcoming myself but I didn't want to introduce anything in the public API that hasn't its equivalent in the Java 8 API (and that most users wouldn't understand anyways).

Regards,
Stefan", 'Hi Stefan,

maybe I was too fast reading the file. After your explanation and reading it again it is clear to me now and it does not need any further change imho.

For the additional field: it can even be private, just not final. So far we do not yet try to disable delegation but it might be interesting for some users that want a fool-proof method to avoid known bugs without changing their code. Actually I never tried to set a system property in an Android application, but it might work as well, as long as it is done before any streamsupport class is accessed. I should create a separate issue explaining the use-case, but it would only be for convenience.', 'Yeah, the "not final" bit is clear :)

You are right, setting the system property works on Android as you say. That's how I'm doing it in my Android tests.

What I don't quite understand is why you want to disable Spliterator delegation at all. If you disable it and use a Collection that employs one of my "native specializations" you run into even more risks the newer the Android version happens to be.
That was one of the main reasons why I've introduced delegation on Android in the first place.

Perhaps this one helps to understand the history: https://github.com/streamsupport/streamsupport/pull/7

Regards,
Stefan

Addendum: Btw, https://sourceforge.net/p/streamsupport/tickets/240/ was the way that LHM bug was detected. Google didn't have tests for that at that time, but I did.', 'Hi Stefan,

maybe my reasoning is flawed, but my idea was to provide users with a consistent behavior on all supported Android versions. By default, delegation would be enabled, but they can use a flag to indicate that they want a "compatibility mode", which uses a possibly slower method but it will be correct on all versions, thus hotfixing bugs in existing Android versions.

Please let me know if the reasoning makes sense to you, so far I did not see that disabling delegation would have a major drawback especially on newer Android systems (it would probably be slower, but that would be acceptable).', 'Hi Thomas,

I believe that's a misunderstanding of what disabling Spliterator delegation is doing.

First of all, (obviously) the Spliterator delegation flag only has an effect on API 24 and above.
Prior to that (API 23 and below, and I'm talking **only** about Android for now) there are two possible cases:

a)
the Collection in question is one of the collections that receive a special treatment (what I used to call "native specialization" in the past).

These are all Collections listed here:

http://static.javadoc.io/net.sourceforge.streamsupport/streamsupport/1.6.2/java8/util/stream/StreamSupport.html#stream-java.util.Collection-

In these cases streamsupport uses a specific Spliterator implementation for that collection that almost invariably accesses implementation details via Unsafe.
This was added (for Android) in 1.1.4-stable, the reasoning being mainly that stream splitting performance in the parallel streams case can potentially be greatly improved.

That's safe and exhaustively tested as long as you are on API 14 - 23.
The more you move into the future (say API >= 26) from that, the greater becomes the risk that some implementation detail in a collection has changed and my hand-rolled Spliterator implementation will fail.
That's the reason why I enabled Spliterator delegation by default on API >= 24. The fact that LHM behaves incorrectly in that case is unfortunate but, anyway, it's an Android bug and not a streamsupport bug (you'd have the same behavior using the real Google implementation).

The reason why the LHM collection views even work on API 24/25 is that they fall under case b)


b) the Collection in question is NOT one of those mentioned above.

In that case, the JRE standard IteratorSpliterator is used, i.e., the Spliterator is based on the Collection's Iterator.


There is a property that enforces the IteratorSpliterator strategy:

"java8.util.Spliterators.assume.oracle.collections.impl=false"

But it **doesn't** work on Android (historically it did from 1.1.4-stable up to 1.3-stable).
This flag is mainly useful for non-OpenJDK, non-Android usages (for example IBM JRE 6/7, though I don't support them officially).


In short: In my view, the safe, "future-proof" way on Android is to always use the default Spliterator delegation, i.e., don't fiddle with the settings unless you have a real reason to do so.
The LHM bug is the only known case. But even in that case, disabling the delegation should only be a short-term workaround.
Better fix your LHM code and reenable the delegation as soon as possible.

That's my point of view on that issue.

Regards,
Stefan', 'Hi Stefan,

ok thanks for the clarification. I was not aware of the fact that the non-native spliterators are custom made and use reflection. I did a quick check in the source code and assumed that the original Oracle implementation is used, but you explained that this is broken on Android.

Considering this, the flag to disable the delegation is indeed not very useful anymore and it is better to include the specific warning about the use of LHM spliterators on Android 24 & 25.', 'Hi Thomas,

the "native" spliterators must be custom since they don't exist on Java 6/7 or API <= 23.
They **are** identical to the Oracle implementation, modulo the fact that they **have** to use reflection since the Oracle Spliterators also access private class internals (which they obviously can do and I can't do without reflection).

The IteratorSpliterator alternative has its own problems. While it works quite well in general getting the Spliterator characteristics right in all cases would be a real challenge.

The decision to remove the "java8.util.Spliterators.assume.oracle.collections.impl=false" flag (for Android) in 1.3.1-stable was quite intentional.
If I had maintained that flag I'd have to test / maintain even more possible combinations than I have today.

Regards,
Stefan', 'Hi Stefan,

I did not realize that you need reflection to perform the same functionality but it makes perfect sense now. The problems with disabling delegation would only be made worse with the announced changes in Android P so it is not really an option anymore. Thanks for the clarification.', 'Right. Btw., the LHM bug in API 24/25 and the workaround for it is explicitly mentioned in the Android API reference.
AFAIK, it was discussed only once on stackoverflow: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/42711433/linkedhashmap-entrysets-order-not-being-preserved-in-a-stream-android

Regards,
Stefan', 'Hi Thomas  @netomi

I just twiddled with a quick'n dirty run of the streamsupport test suite on the Android P emulator.
To my surprise I did get nothing beyond those greylist warnings that you have already identified.

Assuming that no further "dark greylist" problems turn up in the future that should be manageable.
I'll investigate this further after my vacation.

Regards,
Stefan', 'Sounds great, have a nice vacation!', "Hi Thomas,

I've only done a very superficial short test. The two dark greylist warnings (contextClassLoader and AtomicInteger) are probably gone.

I've actually used android-retrostreams for the test but that should make no difference. You can try it yourself with the attached snapshot if you want. A more thorough probe will follow when I'm back.

The CCL issue relates to https://sourceforge.net/p/streamsupport/tickets/275/ and https://bugs.openjdk.java.net/browse/JDK-8172726
That feature is for containerized environments (Servlet Engines and the like) and doesn't have to work on Android (and actually never did work on API >= 24). 
So, I've simply dropped this.

The AtomicInteger issue is caused by my ForkJoinPool.MemBar emulation of the sun.misc.Unsafe fence() methods. I have replaced AtomicInteger by my own "Mock" class.

Cf. the commits:

https://github.com/stefan-zobel/streamsupport/commit/0a9d6f8cdce02f1eaa1e78c4efe13b4b926ec219

https://github.com/stefan-zobel/streamsupport/commit/b1ea3ee305cce96b89e0378d13eaf3bda4af87a4', 'Hi Stefan,

using the version 1.7.0-SNAPSHOT, I get the following warnings:

04-20 10:42:24.684 17294 17294 W zygote  : Accessing hidden field Lsun/misc/Unsafe;->theUnsafe:Lsun/misc/Unsafe; (light greylist, reflection)
04-20 10:42:24.687 17294 17294 W zygote  : Accessing hidden field Ljava/lang/Integer;->value:I (light greylist, reflection)

["If all you want is to run two spaces on the same machine you don't need to configure individual ports for Blitz it'll pick independent ones for itself (default configuration).

You would however have to have separate configuration files per Blitz instance because you want different storage options and you'll almost certainly want to set their names to different things.

Unicast discovery (and indeed multicast) both require you to run a Reggie (Lookup Service instance) which by default runs on port 4160. You could arrange for each Blitz to register via unicast (that requires you set the initialLocators configuration variable - see here: http://www.dancres.org/bjspj/docs/docs/install_guide.html#appb to point at the Reggie address).

You would also need to ensure your clients were given a LookupLocator to connect to the Reggie instance - that can be done in code if you wish.

BUT, I'm wondering why you want unicast discovery? Multicast should work just fine generally.

If you are using the installer, much of what you need can be found in scripts and configuration files bundled in the distribution (there's a readme.txt that explains what needs doing).", "_BUT, I'm wondering why you want unicast discovery? Multicast should work just fine generally._

Multicast does indeed work. However, for a group of developers working on the same subnet, won't multicast return spaces from other machines?", 'Consider the use of groups for segmentation of lookup services and services: http://river.apache.org/doc/specs/html/discovery-spec.html

Assign each developer a group of their own (say their initials if that gives you uniqueness), configure Reggie for that and each Blitz instance (done via initialGroups config variable). Done.', 'I appreciate your suggestion--when helping colleagues debug their services, a group adds another parameter to the mix. Given the potential complexity of the set up, I thought that using localhost everywhere during development would avoid headaches.-)', '"Given the potential complexity of the set up, I thought that using localhost everywhere during development would avoid headaches.-)"

Totally understand - from long painful experience I can highly recommend not going anywhere near localhost - get the groups thing and indeed use of the "right" machine names (not localhost) and such sorted early with scripting or tools or whatever. Leave it until later and it will _hurt bad_ much worse than doing the "right" thing now. Doing it now means a bit more early pain and some education/learning but that's way better than what comes from leaving it late. 

It's kind of a fundamental most fall foul of. Jini/River is a _very_ network centric piece of infrastructure, avoiding the complexities of networks via localhost directly conflicts with that and can hide away a bunch of nasty network problems you're better off knowing about early (many examples of messed up DNS configs and such that cause havoc when moving to test environments and production).', "Ah--good point! I've noticed many of those questions on the mailing lists."]
